item.description:
Please read the section on mandatory equipment carefully!

Let's pickup two 4000 footers for our winter lists. We will meet at the Highland Center in Crawford Notch and ascend to the summit of Mt. Avalon - not a 4000 footer - where there are some very nice views. From there we'll continue our ascent to the summit of Mt. Field. From Mt. Field we'll follow the Willey Range Trail to its junction with the A-Z and take the Mt. Tom Spur to the summit of Mt. Tom. There are some nice views from the summit, but if conditions permit we'll take a short detour over to a beautiful overlook that has spectacular views. Our descent will be via the A-Z trail and the Avalon trail, bypassing the summit of Mt. Avalon this time around.

The total distance will be 7.5 miles and we'll gain 3019 feet in elevation. Book time is 6 hours and 20 minutes.

This being winter, we will need to start promptly at 9:00 AM. We will also hike at a comfortable but steady pace. We will have lunch on either Mt. Field or Mt. Tom depending on the time.

Also, please be aware that conditions are quite variable in the winter. Conditions may require us to forgo one or the other summit, or they may require us to alter our route. To quote Ed Viesturs, "Reaching the summit is optional. Getting down is mandatory."

Please note that dogs are not permitted on this hike.

Details

What: Mount Tom and Mount Field
Distance: 7.45 miles round trip
Elevation Gain: 3019'
Difficulty: Moderate
Pace: Moderate.
Exposure: Little to no exposure.
Book Time:6 1/2 hours.

Is This Hike for Me?

This hike will be at amoderate pace under winter conditions. Expect ice and deep snow. The trails are relatively sheltered however expect windy conditions on and near the summits. Expect several stream crossings. While there should be thick ice bridges this time of year, that's not a guarantee. Stream crossings can be tricky in winter. We will keep the group together throughout the hike. Therefore, please plan to hike at a pace that will be comfortable for everyone. We will gain about 3019' during the hike. Expect several steep sections both up and down. The views are very good from the summits. Weather conditions and time constraints will be monitored throughout the hike. Those conditions may result in a decision to turn back before the summits should safety become an issue.

To participate you should:


  • Be comfortable hiking UPHILL at about 1.5 to 2.0 miles per hour at a 15% incline for about 4 miles.
  • Be comfortable walking at least 8 miles on uneven terrain including ice and deep snow.
  • Have sturdy winter hiking boots suitable for cold weather. No Sneakers!
  • Have rain, snow, and wind protection. No Ponchos!
  • Be able to carry at least 2 liters of water. (Remember, 1 liter weighs 2 pounds!)
  • Be in good physical condition.


Weather and Trail Conditions

Microspikes and Snowshoes - I fully expect to need some form of traction on this hike. At least Microspikes will be necessary. If you have snowshoes, you should bring them as well. While we will not know for certain if we need them, snowshoes should be a standard part of your winter pack this time of year. If you don't have them, you may rent them at EMS or REI.

Boots - A pair of winter hiking boots is mandatory. You will be hiking in snow for over 6-hours, so you cannot get away with your summer hiking boots in January or February. You do NOT need plastic boots for general hiking anywhere in NH, but you WILL need waterproof winter boots comfort rated to at least -30 degrees. (No, we don't typically encounter those temperatures, but boots with that rating will keep you warm while you're having your lunch on snow or ice.) Remember, you will be spending some time standing or sitting around during brief breaks, summit views, taking pictures, or having lunch. Warm winter boots will keep you comfortable and safe.

Water - Finally, you see the note below that your water must be in wide-mouth plastic bottles. It is time to put your hydration systems - e.g. Camelbak's - away for the winter. While they do sell insulated tubes for the hydration systems, quite frankly they do not work. The entrance to the tube where it connects to the bladder still freezes, leaving you with a bladder full of inaccessible water. Therefore, unless it is unseasonably warm for this hike, you'll need to carry water the old fashioned way. Be sure to get wide mouth bottles and be sure to carry them upside down. (Water freezes from the top down.)

Mandatory Equipment List as of 1 January 2011.
This list could change based on trail conditions just prior to the hike.


  • Microspikes or Hillsounds. (See note below.)
  • Synthetic shirt and waterproof pants. No cotton. No jeans.
  • Sturdy Winter Hiking Boots suitable for cold weather. No Sneakers or summer boots.
  • Rain / Wind Jacket with hood. No Ponchos.
  • Warm fleece layer.
  • Warm gloves or preferably mittens. (2 pair is strongly recommended.)
  • Warm fleece or wool hat.
  • Balaclava
  • Sunglasses
  • 2 liters Water in wide-mouth bottles. No hydration systems!
  • Headlamp
  • Spare Lithium batteries for Headlamp. Bring Lithium, not Alkaline batteries.
  • Trail Snacks suitable for freezing weather. (You don't want something that turns into a rock when frozen.)
  • Lunch


Optional Gear:


  • Hiking Poles - strongly recommended
  • Snowshoes - strongly recommended
  • Gaiters
  • Camera / Binoculars

    No Jeans, Sneakers, or Cotton clothing on the hike! Since it is winter, this will be strictly enforced.

    Carpool Option

    I don't have a carpool setup for this since I'll be driving up the night before. If you wish to arrange a carpool, please use the comments section to coordinate with other hikers.

    Dining Options

    Dinner

    We will plan to stop at Fabians on Route 301 for dinner after the hike.

    Directions to Trailhead

    From Providence, RI:

    Please allow 4 hours travel time from Providence


    • Take Route 95 North.
    • Take Route 93 North to NH.
    • Take Exit 35 (Route 3 North) towards Twin Mountain.
    • Turn Right in Twin Mountain onto Route 302.
    • The Highland Center will be on your right about 10 miles down.
    • Park near the exit from the Highland Center, ignoring the sign that says it's reserved for guests.


    Trails and Other Info

    I will send a detailed trail map to those that RSVP Yes.

    Our route will be as follows:

    • Avalon Trail to summit of Mt. Avalon
    • Avalon Trail to summit of Mt. Field
    • Willey Range Trail to jct A-Z Trail
    • A-Z Trail to jct Mt. Tom Spur
    • Mt. Tom Spur to summit of Mt. Tom
    • Mt. Tom Spur to jct A-Z Trail
    • A-Z Trail to jct Avalon Trail
    • Avalon Trail to Highland Center Parking


    Contact Information

    I will provide my cell phone number along with a link to a detailed trail map to all "YES" RSVPs the week of the hike. I strongly encourage you to call me if you have any questions about the hike or the gear required.

    Note about Yak Trax

    Yak Trax recently released a style of traction support similar to Microspikes and Hillsounds. Within the last week, however, I have received three separate reports of these new Yak Trax failing. Two of those situations resulted in falls. Since three separate hikers have recently found them unreliable, they are not considered suitable traction devices for hikes that I lead up north. Apologies to anyone that purchased Yak Trax, however your safety and the safety of the group as a whole is paramount.

    For now, the following devices are considered suitable traction options for hiking up north. Note that neither Hillsound Trail Crampons nor Katoola Microspikes are a substitute for full crampons in all conditions:

    Hillsound Trail Crampons
    Katoola Microspikes
    full Crampons (numerous brands)

    Liability Waiver

    As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
